_T8j2ZH5DF3QqNsMjFTnQg.text: Love this place! Great food!  Staff can at times have bad attitude.   My only real complaint.. you're really going to charge $1.50 to add a small amount of onion to an Indian taco????? I can buy two whole entire onions for that price.   I've came before and wasn't charged for onion, then came today and was told it was $1.50 extra, that's ridiculous.   I could see $1.50 for extra meat... BUT ONION!   Update: just got my order, and I'm pretty disappointed. I've been eating here since there previous location, and this is the first time I was given like a smear of beans. I paid 9$ for bread basically.   Get it together Fry Bread House.

Photo of The Fry Bread House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. After I tried to spread around what little beans I had.

PYYvJUzlX5XYMIh2Nk351g.text: Yum - great service and crispy fry bread.  My husband got a savory one with chorizo and beans, I got a sweet one with butter and cinnamon sugar.  We didn't spent a lot of time here, because we had already stuffed our faces with a lot of other food, but were intent on getting ourselves fry bread.  If we'd had more time, I would've wanted to return to get a full meal with a savory fry bread, but we didn't have time.  Highly recommend having a lunch here in Phoenix.

photos.caption: Photo of The Fry Bread House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Chorizo and beans fry bread (in the back) with a butter/cinnamon/sugar fry bread.

2Y54mpTRlKj8neOkaK9gXQ.text: First visit! Insanely delicious!  Greeted with a smile and great suggestions!  The unsweetened tea was perfection!  Chips and sauce? . Then the Indian tacos!  Wow! Lives up to the hype !  I will be back.. what an amazing treat!

pUYv1-VnRU3_oMwd9iBYCg.text: Quite indulgent, they have very generous portions, and friendly, quick service! The environment is cozy and welcoming. The fry bread is very big and on the messy side. The flavor of the fry bread is similar to a Taco Bell chalupa, but 100x better! We split the ultimate taco and a veggie burro, both were really tasty! There was plenty to share, make sure to get extra napkins!

msMfOpifzMuNmudHd4c_IA.text: I found Fry Bread house while walking On a stretch of an Phoenix street after nightfall, terrified that there weren't any people out walking around.   Coming in was a total relief, because the environment is friendly, warm, and the ease of ordering left me totally relaxed. And oh the FRY BREAD is the gloriously thin and chewy puffed-up dough that's been topped generously with beans, lettuce, and cheese (hello, Indian taco). They don't serve booze here, but being around boozed-up folks was exactly what I didn't need. The enormous taco ran me up a cool $7 USD. Great place with great affordable food.

photos.caption: Photo of The Fry Bread House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Sunday December night
Photo of The Fry Bread House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Indian taco

UsVs3JD5o8bhlebmjAo5WQ.text: So this is my first ever Yelp review And iam excited and happy that it is for a really good place like The Fry Bred House.    Well after reading lots of great reviews about this place and never ever after 19 years in Az And actually visited the Navajo Nation a few times, I decide to go and eat My first Indian Fry Bread !!    The place is smaller than I thought but it's very friendly and cozy. The service is fast. It took no more than 5 min for my name to be called after I pay $8.95 for a Red Meat

miZYx6BI8-PrHEEoV9W1Bw.text: Friendly service, homely atmosphere, and they use toys instead of numbers to keep track of orders! Fun! Frybread is made fresh (as it needs to be, otherwise you get chewy rounds of grease-dough), and is the perfect vehicle on which to transport red chile into your mouth (or green chile, or stew...I mean, it's your choice, really). The chumuth is deliciously buttery. Definitely a required stop next time I'm in PHX. Tohono O'odham owned; support Native business!

photos.caption: Photo of The Fry Bread House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. frybread,  red chili and chumuth. support native businesses!

6wK7iGGOiDVEDomrRXzXiA.text: The best nachos ever and we have had nachos all over the world. Great taco and dessert.  Will definitely recomend

CynzQ-hZe5YrtjOKsXvawQ.text: Authentic fry bread! If you want the real deal....this is it! Yum!  If you are craving the calories and fry bread, this place makes authentic fry bread. They have several options but my fav as a vegetarian is the vegetarian taco which comes with beans, hatch green Chile, cheese, diced onion, lettuce and sour cream. Don't forget to ask for salsa to spice it up! My friend prefers the green Chile taco but if you don't want fried bread, their menu has other options like burros, tamales, stews, etc...I cant speak about those items because I've never tried. If in the area and if you want fry bread, I would definitely recommend!

photos.caption: Photo of The Fry Bread House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Green Chile beef taco

P_vpGPb3enfA9cyz2q1iRA.text: Love this local spot. Been a huge fan for many years. What a great menu of items like homemade tamales and amazing frybread. They are the best in the frybread world! Prices are good and food is always fresh.

photos.caption: Photo of The Fry Bread House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Two of the best items the Red Beef Tamale and the Navajo Taco.
Photo of The Fry Bread House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. A local favorite

4y8BEbMVPRMrtlaNBSp3HQ.text: Traveled in from out of town, I went here years ago when it was at a different location. Took my husband he had the red chili and I had the green both were delicious. Also got the kiddy bears with honey!

MEA0JR79VuHQKAjgyaRSlQ.text: I was first exposed to The Fry Bread House during their days operating on Indian School Road. They've since moved to 7th Avenue in the "suicide lane" area as I like to call it. I decided that it was time to pay them a long-overdue visit.  Now, one must keep in mind that I've always placed fry bread under the same umbrella as deep dish pizza. When done right, it's good, but it's something that I'd never be able to eat regularly. But occasionally, when the mood strikes to eat something incredibly unhealthy, but yet satisfyingly delicious, this is one of those places that pulls it off quite well.  At this point, I've only tried their red chili beef taco and haven't quite developed the courage to experiment further. The red chili beef is classified as hot, but by the standards of most, it's pretty mild. Ingredients are all good quality, with the fry bread itself being a notch above what you'd find at other places. It's fluffy, it's chewy, and it packs some solid flavor.  If your stomach can handle dessert, I've found that the chocolate and butter combo works well, although there's a variety of other dessert options to choose from if you're more into cinnamon-style. It's also surprisingly much lighter than you'd expect. I was able to finish both my taco and half of the dessert bread quite easily, which is something that I didn't expect to be able to do going in.  I've made a mental note that when I return, it's high time that I finally try the green chili that everyone mentions, to see whether or not I've been missing out.  Highly recommended!

7ewYACMd8K2gSB1E5C6sBw.text: The food is pretty good. But they have so many rules. Like it's run by a controlling sociopath amount of rules. The rules are written everywhere. At first I thought it was just me but two other friends thought the same thing about the place. The strangest one is you can only have one suds refill. Is it really that big of a problem if someone asks for a second refill?

bhp2o_ipEpWv-mWToJgu0Q.text: There is no arguing that the Indian fry breads are super delicious, tasteful, hot and enjoyable to eat. I order the bean and cheese  fried bread, which was made to perfection. Beans were just right and why I say that is because if beans aren't cooked or seasoned the right way, it can make a huge difference.   Make sure to order a large drink of your choice because it isn't one of those self serve soda machines and they charge for refill.    Ordering food wasn't at my expectation, considering the employee wasn't very pleasant or friendly.   Now let's talk about the environment which caused me to rate this a 3. Environment is so important to me in a establishment, especially in a restaurant. As soon as we walked in, the employee was cleaning the restroom, mind you the restroom is right in the entrance, so as she is cleaning it, the whole restaurant smelled like cleaning chemicals which is very toxic for my food and the fact that I'm pregnant I wasn't to happy about the smell. It was very unsanitary and a wrong time to clean when the doors had just opened for business that day.  I'm sure the people felt the same way behind us in line.   So my experience was ok, but luckily the food was good.

dyStr54W7Qu6bn1nIKijdQ.text: I went to this place for the first time yesterday with my brother and I was not quite sure about it because I'm not a big fan of fry bread. People get surprised when I tell them I don't really care for fry bread because I'm actually Native American and I always get "what Native doesn't like fry bread?"  I ended up ordering two tamales, one red and one green. I really enjoyed the red tamale and would definitely get it again, the green was too spicy for my liking. I love spicy but the green tamale was just too eye watering and tongue burning. My brother had a taste of the green tamale and said although it was really spicy, that it was good. My brother ended up getting a taco which was fry bread served with beans and ground beef on top, along with lettuce and cheese. I tried the taco and it was BOMB! I wish I would have gotten my own. It's a very good filling portion with very good flavor. For dessert we got fry bread with butter, powdered sugar, and cinnamon and that just made me love this spot more. I would recommend this place to everyone I know and would be back very soon! I guess you can say I like fry bread now

eWDfxazuFSEH9JUaVxPGEg.text: This place takes me back to New Mexico and the yummy red chili!! Amazing food, i love their indian tacos !!

photos.caption: Photo of The Fry Bread House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Indian taco !!!

dnD-kegaXn5V3JSfS-yzNg.text: Ultimate taco with green chile beef was amazing!!! Posole was underwhelming at best though. Portion was HUGE! Staff was very friendly and helpful. Nice atmosphere. Base pricing was very reasonable for the large portions. Beware of add-ons though! $1.25 for lettuce or jalapeno seems kind of insane to me.

ZntjNn4SKI2ZWU8LOvFb5Q.text: I will always think of this place as "Ponchos", even though it hasen't been there forEVER.  I walked in and it's pretty spacious, it was just about 11am so it wasn't busy. Right away I noticed the ugly sheets hanging to block the view of the kitchen. Honestly it just looks tacky and needs to be changed. An employee was cleaning the bathrooms and greeted me as I waited in line to order. The employee taking my order was nice enough.  I got the Green Chili Taco and a Lent tamale. The outside of the frybread was good. But the all that gooey green chili basically tore through the frybread because it was so thin. Not good. The chili itself was egh. The lent tamale which had corn and chili was better. But they were just reheated in the microwave before being served. I observed the cashier tell the cook who was reaching for the refrigerator that "there's one more Lent." It was okay I guess, the outer edges of the masa was a bit hard from being reheated to long... sigh... It just isn't the same when they were at the old tiny place.  The also had a Marketplace for Indian jewelry. I didn't walk over becuase they tend to be overpriced. But it was in the other half of the seating area with a little handwritten sign over the door way. Between the marketplace and kitchen I guess was the "cleaning supply area", all their supplies were in plan view becuase the sheet was pushed and held to the side. It just doesn't look good.   It may seem like a step up into a bigger place, but its actually a step down.

M4z6rTBwLjs6BiRPB4hJqQ.text: This used to be my favorite place to get Indian fry bread when the state fair wasn't around. This is my first time going to the new location and it's kind of scary. Inside, it looks like an old Mexican restaurant and they have cloth hanging everywhere to hide windows and openings. The staff doesn't try to make conversation at all. As far as the food goes, the fry bread itself was great but the beans were cold. I don't know if I'll return. I'm kinda disappointed.

photos.caption: Photo of The Fry Bread House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. The fry bread was fresh, the beans inside were cold. Womp Womp woooooomp

xD4WfUy8v_7ppSTnnSFHeA.text: If your feeling the craving of a homemade fry bread but don't want to put in the work, GO HERE! It was delicious! I got the Indian taco with green chili beef and it was a tad on the spicy side but the flavor was on point.

JQXypTUN9fz-ggCjdqGUjA.text: I love this place, every single time I am in Phoenix I have to stop here, I have followed it from all its locations. I love fry bread. I usually get the Ultimate Taco but sometimes the red or green chili. But I have a sweet tooth so I usually get the powdered sugar and honey fry bread too. Portions are huge! So, so, good.

uuUNcYXCUdFfBq6xCcLeDQ.text: We had takeout. It was BOMB. We had ultimate tacos, hominy soup, and a bean and cheese taco. So much food. Great prices. Delicious.

AJd1aRghZhb4b4t1wchm-Q.text: Easily the most unassuming James Beard winning establishment that you will ever visit. A bit of a dive but the best a great place  to get introduced to some of the culinary heritage of our Native friends.

WuSlhQA0U-ohWTdnJ87-Rg.text: Before we vacationed to the Phoenix area I did some research on where and what to eat. I was looking for good eats and hidden gems that locals love. And then.... I found FRY BREAD!!! Why are they not making this everywhere in the US. It's like an elephant ear as the bread used for a sandwich, with many option as stuffers for the insides. We ordered the beef and green taco, whoa are these things huge!! I was expecting the same as the Mexican restaurants that they have in Chicago where you order two or 3 small tacos.   So be warned that 1 fry bread taco = 3 Chicago Mexican Joint tacos  Now that I'm back home, this food is probably the most thought of during my summer, every time I'm at a fair or carnival I'm wishing they had a Fry Bread cart.

photos.caption: Photo of The Fry Bread House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Our first Fry Bread! Didn&#39;t know what to expect, so we ordered a taco version (on the top) and a green chilli w/ beef (bottom).

UIc68uU06TfvgXC4f3bFhQ.text: Came in today to try something different usually get the green chili stew which is the best.  So I tried the posole been awhile since I had any but wasn't impressed.  Should of stuck with the green chili, the posole didn't have any flavor and hominy tasted old.

O33QxlQYGmVJiIdO6pifdw.text: Yummy fry bread and green chili chicken tamale that was super good, green chile stew is the way to go and a fry bread taco with ground beef we shared everything!!being from Colorado I've had better green chili however it's hard to find in Arizona and impossible in Southern California so felt spoiled to be able to get it here yummy my recommendation indulge

lvSP0WLPdxv0UDTlBx-ELg.text: DO NOT GO TO 1003 E Indian School!!!! They have moved to 7th Avenue South of Camelback Rd. near Joe's Diner.  Great food, but they keep moving!

TjKmye4AYmnALzK0yXyypg.text: Gross.  Flies all over the dining room. Ripped up upholstery. Big divots in the floor where  structural elements were removed and never patched.  Now the food.  I ordered the ground beef taco. The meat had absolutely no seasoning and was oily. The fry bread was not fully cooked and oily. The scant bit of lettuce that was put on the taco was wilted and brown. And the salsa the counter attendant raved about we couldn't try because the ketchup type bottle they put it in was sealed shut with gunk.  2 bites in and we left. Waste of money and now I have a stomach ache.

Es9gbegxTQu5z6yzxDurTA.text: Simply amazing! I had the green chile stew with a plain fry bread and I was blown away with how awesome it was. The place is a little run down and there are no lights outside to tell you that the place is even there but it is so worth it. Make sure you get dessert too!

WrjHTZtzcGpM34_zATxQuQ.text: OMG!!  This place was amazing!!  My first time here. The place is nice and clean.  I had the ultimate green taco and it was delicious!!  Definitely coming back.

lalRI3sY9KgPT68Qbg7z7w.text: Th food was awesome! Red chili taco frybread was awesome. The inside is run down and could use a face lift but the food more than compensates.

0PcSVHHuzxxLHUdcodBxiA.text: I've driven by this restaurant over 100 times.  I was finally curious enough to give it a try.  Because I had read the reviews here, I knew what I would order for my test lunch.  A simple red chile beef taco.  I went ultimate - all the toppings.  Holy crap!  I hate it when I drive by a gem 100 times without giving it a try.  This is going to be a regular for sure.  It's a 5-star bit of food wrapped in a weak service and marginal cleanliness package.  The table we sat at was sticky, the guy who brought our food dropped it splattering a salsa bottle all over the table.  They give you only 1 see-through napkin for what is a messy meal, and although he said more were available - not handily.  Treat it like a giant immobile food-truck.  I'll make it a to-go place, but I'll be "to-going" once a week.

udmrEYoIs0efa-ESC-Q2LQ.text: Very good red chile fry bread tacos, and honey/sugar desert fry bread served sliced ;).

fkpPy7U_7NZXaWaTtAzOFg.text: The original location was wonderful both in food quality and atmosphere. Then the move to the dungeon on East Indian School. Once was enough for me. Dingy, dark, and dirty. Now the new location on 7th Avenue has renewed our interest. Back to an attractive place and the quality of food seemed to improve back to it's old wonderful style. The green chili and posole are great. Glad to have them back after the previous horror shop.

Lsl0APMIZw6AHg4XTR-cIA.text: Little slow on the service but my God the food is phenomenal especially the Green Chile Stew (you better like spicy!)

3uu6ZK-55HPE9E8XWc7Z9Q.text: Love! Love! Love! This place is absolutely amazing!! Don't let the appearance fool you... The food and the service are top-notch!!!!!

zQbJwgcf1nAf1slW_4bnEQ.text: Let me preface this by saying I normally am ambivalent to fry bread. I don't hate it but I don't love it either. Went here intending on just having a small bite but ended up ordering an ultimate shredded beef taco and chips and salsa.   The chips and salsa were really good and the portion was surprisingly large, but the taco was absolutely amazing. It's big enough that if you can finish it, you might slip into a food coma at the table and it was fantastic. I also tried a beef tamale and it was equally good. Check this place out and bring your appetite, maybe your neighbor's appetite too.

aM52DQ6XMO-2m3aKYo4IoQ.text: This restaurant is amazing. The food is great, and the prices are fair.   Some favorites include: green chili stew (soooo spicy, but delicious), pozole, tamales, and basically anything with the fry bread.   Two specials really stick out to me: the squash burro - super light, but savory and comforting, and the kokoji, which is tasty mass smothered in their green chili.   They make all the food to order, so don't be surprised if you're waiting 10+ minutes on a busy night for your food to come out.   We love bringing out of town guests to Fry Bread and we're happy that every single person we've brought, loves it as much as we do.

Pz8QxyvdIrqswY5IvTiRXQ.text: Hubby & and stopped here while in the area, and sooooo enjoyed every delicious bite!!  It was one of those meals where you get a little sad when you're getting to the last few bites even though you feel quite full!  We live about 40 minutes away, but we're already planning some way to 'be in the area' again very soon!! Can't wait!!

NPR9J77DaMvJ_CMGjB50zQ.text: Hmmmmmm. Where do I start... For starters, their employees are very friendly, and their decoration is quaint and cute. I moved down the street and I drive past this place every day so I decided to give it a try. I got the beef taco with cheese, beans, and lettuce wrapped in fry bread. A very unhealthy meal, but it will surely fill you up. It was decent I think but nothing really to rave about. Personally I think it would have been better with more toppings of some sort.   Then, I got the fry bread with honey and powdered sugar. This one was just toooo sweet, it's overflowing with honey. Would have been better if they just drizzled the honey and added powdered sugar.   I got some soda too, and I only took a sip because it tasted weird, like there's something else on it...   Aside from that all in all, it was an okay experience. If I do go next time, I will probably try the fry bread with chocolate.

Photo of The Fry Bread House - Phoenix, AZ, United States

8-9zvQdxUz0wk1zM74KKeg.text: Awesome food. This place was on most Yelp lists of places to eat in Phoenix, so naturally I made sure to stop by and see what was the deal.  It's a fairly small space with simple decor. There is a menu on the wall by the counter were you place your order. Then they give you a token to place on your table and someone will deliver the food to your table. Service was quick. On my first visit I had the vegetable tamale, my second visit I shared a chocolate fry bread and cinnamon and spice fry bread. Both times, I was very satisfied with my choices. I even looked up the recipes for fry bread. I will be back if I'm in the area.

photos.caption: Photo of The Fry Bread House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Chocolate fry break and cinnamon, butter fry bread.

OmEP2RCjw6pc0qfhM8wb1g.text: The fry bread is delicious. That's all you really need to know. This place is small and perhaps seems a bit bare bones, but everything we ordered was delicious. The service was fast and I had amazingly authentic fry bread. You can get the delicious fry bread tacos. I had mine with spicy chorizo, and it even tasted great warmed up the next day. All the dessert fry bread options looked amazing. Nothing really beats plain fry bread with honey on it though!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Fry Bread House - Phoenix, AZ, United States

I19G2UkRL4qcgrkDFFXlVw.text: Came here with a friend for lunch. We arrived at 11:30 and it wasn't busy at all. It's a cute place inside and I like it better than their previous location. I ordered the Indian Taco that came with beans, lettuce, and cheese. So good! And so filling! I had wanted to try the butter and chocolate one for dessert but after finishing mine off there was absolutely no way. I recommend splitting one with someone if you want dessert afterwards!

photos.caption: Photo of The Fry Bread House - Phoenix, AZ, United States

anwV2RY163tUTfxeOjYp9g.text: Tasty Native American food that i don't have to travel to Southern border of Arizona to eat. Red chili stew is traditional and the best thing to try if your new to this menu.

EPyCxeDR3QRnMYp5rRDSBw.text: Came here with a few coworkers to celebrate a birthday, because everyone wanted some fry bread.    The location was okay, parking was very limited, so I would recommend carpooling and probably come during non-busy hours.  The service was fast, and friendly, and the food was good.  The food is very heavy, so it might give you food coma when you get back to work.    I didn't have to use the loo so not sure what it is like.  Seating in the location was limited as well since they are always busy.  Overall a good experience, don't see why we wouldn't come back.

5fdP5OCZZzYjp3BjwhcDUQ.text: I've been craving Navajo Fry Bread tacos for years and everytime I visit somehow I never make the time to find it. Happy to report, my sister guided me to Fry Bread House tonight and I was not disappointed!   Adorable place with a nice dining room.  The tacos were huge, stuffed with the requisites: pinto beans, cheese, shredded lettuce and then your choice of chili's, meats, etc. I had the hatch green chili deluxe taco with sour cream. Spicy and so so good. Tamales were moist and On Point.   The only problem was I didn't leave room for dessert! Next time, next time.

qZCi7y1SSEaganEBcPuutA.text: Gave The Fry Bread House a try and it was pretty good! They only thing I would agree with other reviews on about this place is the amount of beans they give you. I ordered 2 to go and there was a very small amount of beans inside. I opened it up and tried to spread the beans out and it was more lettuce & tomatoes than there was beans... Other than that it was pretty good. The red salsa is also pretty good... Would I give them another try? Probably not...

cK0zffY2-pCz-dr0bcfZJw.text: What a fun little restaurant!!! As soon as you come in, you can feel the fun with ropes coming from the ceiling and to the ground (I think it was a game); there's cute little figurines at the counter, and they give you toy food to decipher your order. Super super adorable.   The cinnamon sugar fry bread was super super delicious, absolutely loved it! I ordered the beef taco and my husband ordered the green chili beef taco. They were a bit disappointing unfortunately as the beef's grease soaked into the fry bread which caused it to fall apart and since the fry bread was already slightly greasy to begin with it ended up being a bit of a mess... to be fair, it may just be that we didn't eat it fast enough or knew how to eat it properly? But we really wanted to enjoy the authentic experience but just couldn't get past the mound it turned into.

Photo of The Fry Bread House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Cinnamon sugar fry bread -- DELICIOUS

7Hi8DO7iPAI1AqwP8MoR7g.text: I used to eat Navajo tacos many years ago when I lived on and near the reservation and always wished for a good one but it's not something you'd find in Hawaii.  This trip to Phoenix, fry bread was on top of my list so I asked around and Frybread House was recommended.  Did not disappoint!  The green chilies in the beef were a bit hot for me but fortunately the woman who served us was very helpful and suggested on the side. We got one green and one red and the red was great! We ended up getting two to go for my niece's boyfriend and he also said he'd definitely go back.  The honey Frybread was perfect for dessert but I had to eat it later because we were all so full and happy. Aheehee

photos.caption: Photo of The Fry Bread House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Navajo taco with red chili beef.

ZI0S2lDnb84EoShuiZKESw.text: This place is bomb. Call ahead and you can skip the line. The green chili means business and the honey fry bread is magical. If you're ever in the mood to try something a little different, this should be your stop.

SozWGMdw6-Q9hCxJGT5aAA.text: We ordered the Green Chili, Bean & Cheese Frybreads, Bean & Cheese Burrito, and chips and salsa.  DELICIOUS!  We all LOVED it.  The salsa is a red chili pepper, so it's spicy and has that red chili taste.  Doesn't seem to be any tomatoes in the salsa.  Just saying, not complaining.  DoorDashed the order and they were 10 minutes ahead of schedule.   We'll definitely be back for food and dessert.

tzKSkloE-wNBQM17KzyI-Q.text: Really nifty atmosphere with quirky decorations and a spunky location. Food is delicious and if you have a taste for high quality fry bread made just like grandma then come eat here!

photos.caption: Photo of The Fry Bread House - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of The Fry Bread House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Atmosphere at the fry bread house!

YWNa-aUGWmr28ViwWPbfbw.text: The pozole, tamales, and frybread (bigger than your head!) are to die for. Everything is always served hot and fresh. It's a small, cozy place with limited seating but you can usually find a place to sit. I've also seen many people get takeout orders as well.

photos.caption: Photo of The Fry Bread House - Phoenix, AZ, United States

puWGB4cAfKs89PvbO6jIew.text: Amazing! I have waited a long time for this taco! I was in the area years ago and had a fry bread taco, lived it and knew I would come back so day for more!  You better be hungry! These are big and they are delicious!

abPPF0bbgwG1UhLx7vAWSQ.text: I have been coming to the Fry Bread House since I found it 15 years ago in a Fodors guide book. The first time I tried Fry bread was on the Navajo reservation, and this place totally reminds me of that!  We almost always get a bowl of chili and side of fry bread (the Joe's special) I prefer the green chilli, but the red is also great. Dessert of chocolate or honey Fry bread is a great way to end the meal.  This place has consistently great food. Fast casual, so you order and they bring it out to you.

cN9sWhvVyGzGZmmYG38ULw.text: I typically wait all year for the fair to come around and bring me to paradise with fry bread. But this gem, wow! I've had the green & red child "taco". And it was so heartfelt and delicious. I went home that night on Pinterest to find what can I make that was similar to this place. It's far from my location, but I just press the "hide mileage" button on my car since it's that yum'o. I brought one of my gal friends and she is total hippie. She was even hit with the where have I been my whole card. Genuine food and welcoming service.

M-PivLyymZ7LIHuCOTgI9g.text: How can something so simple taste sooo good? I wish there were one more on the west side. I hate going to the fair to get my fix of fry bread. There needs to be one of these on every  corner of the compass in Phoenix! As Rachel Ray would say, "Yummy!"

Y16_cNIR7Ghk-3oIGQExLw.text: word to my peeps! great "soul food"!!! usually can't get this stuff unless you are at a pow wow, or a feast day. True authentic "skin" cuisine.

Vn7i9EI6-MGryr2X8Xkt_g.text: Super tasty!  I was worried it would be crowded so we got there about 11:45 and it was no problem to order and find a seat,  The staff was super nice and volunteered to cut them in half for us since we were sharing.  I think the Green Chili taco was our favorite, the one with just ground beef was a bit boring.  I'd love to go back and try some others. The dessert fry bread with butter and powdered sugar was awesome.  I didn't like the one with chocolate near as much.

FHmnSsqgcFg4AHXsmCXkDw.text: Well worth the two hours you will need to spend at the gym working it all off.

AV7tNNxJMNyo81eI1yZ0Dw.text: Respect the Fry Bread house and the native culture.  A small place located on the west side of 7th St. and Indian School Rd, in Central Phoenix.  This corner is a strong developing area in Phoenix along with 7th St in general.  This is a popular Phoenix lunch and dinner restaurant.  Its places like this that reflects the word of mouth when there's good food.  Allow your palate choose the right Fry Bread, from vegi to meat lovers.  Did i mention their freaking huge. Don't for get your appetite.

fHnU1Iw2HcvVTq0dRvqHoQ.text: The last time i went was on saturday after the fiesta bowl parade, the food was so good the last time that we decided to go after the parade. It was very busy. jfe2DelqnMkWVV8su8VjeQ.text: The Fry Bread House is fantastic- not healthy by any means, but delicious all the same.  The menu is short, but filled with both meal fry breads and dessert.   I had beans, cheese and tomatoes on mine and then split one of the powdered sugar breads for dessert with my friend. Both were excellent.  The restaurant itself is supercasual- you order at the counter and sit at little tables.  The food is very reasonable and the staff is friendly.  Definitely not a restaurant to miss!

iGv4gGdzWOc5MWY6VzK24Q.text: Great fry bread, but what stops this place from getting 4 or 5 stars from me was how ordinary the rest of the taco was.  I ordered chorizo and I think they gave me carnitas instead, but I didnt have the guts to tell them just in case I was wrong.  Who knows, maybe that's their version of chorizo.

dly9U2qFJ73GqH52M1GcAw.text: My older sister kept raving about this place and by kept raving about this place I axed her to stop talking about it because she kept putting it on higher pedestals and I feel that things shouldn't be built up so much.  She stopped talking about it until after I finally told her I went and man, was it worth all that hype. I went to Phoenix to see the White Sox take on the Diamondbacks and I flew in that Friday morning.  After I got to the hotel I quickly found my way to the light rail which took me north to Indian School Road.  And then I caught a bus for a quick slide over to 7th avenue.  I ordered a red taco AND a green taco thinking that they weren't too big but perhaps I should have paid attention to what was on other people's plates.  They were both really, really good and if I had to pick a better one, I'd say that the red chili was slightly better than the green. The red tamale was OUTSTANDING and next time I go in there I'm a gonna order at least 5 of those.  Did you read that last sentence?  I repeat, the red tamale was OUTSTANDING. The inside of the place wasn't much to look at but if your food is that good, then who really gives a fuck what the decor looks like?  Helpful tip:  Go there really hungry.

M7FhSTK0oOdh9DgrAgQDMA.text: I went here with my parents when they came to visit.  Our first experience with fry bread was down in Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument several years ago, and we were looking to try more.  The chili taco was very good -- not what I expected, but who cares when it's good?  We also got cinnamon and sugar fry bread, and honey fry bread.  *nom!*  The only bad thing was it's fried (duh) so the grease factor is extremely high.  I really can't eat a taco AND share a dessert bread without getting sick.  Unless you are used to eating a lot of unhealthy foods, pick either the meal or the dessert (I'd pick the dessert!) or go with a friend and split everything to cut down on your grease factor.

2EVQ_MzAWFqfNG9b0ksqoQ.text: Hey, want something SO GOOD??  So good you will want to ignore your doctor's advice and eat there every day!?   Something that will make you weak in the knees and leave you begging for more?  Go. To. The Fry Bread House. GO. Now.  If you know native american fry bread, if you don't, doesn't matter. This place rocks. They have an assortment of native style dishes, like the red or green chili stew (that come with or without the bread - but puh-leeeeeze get the bread) and mexican/indian type things. Today I had the indian taco; re-fried beans, cheese and lettuce wrapped in, what was that? Deep fried flipping nirvana-esque bread did you say? Oh hell yes. And the salsa is pretty good too.   Then just to make sure I would require an ambulance ride home complete with frequent use of the defibrillator, we topped it all off with fry bread covered in honey. Oh my god, my mouth is watering. If you live Az, if you are planning to visit, just make sure you stop by. I promise you won't be sad you did.  Ok, I think I have rambled enough and hope that you all understand, that uhhmm, I really really really really like fry bread!!!

RQs5LE9IMZSgKzgmGTRI7g.text: Ever since my visit to the AZ state fair as a child, I've had a weakness for fry bread.  I loved everything about this place -- from the local papers about Indian reservation events to the chit chat with the guy behind the counter about which Navajo tribe managed the restaurant -- and I recommend it to anyone visiting the greater Phoenix area.  Personally, I like fry bread "as is", particularly after a quick dip in the red beef chile or hominy beef stew, but those wanting something with a bit more pizazz can order a wide array of sweet or savor toppings (cheese, honey, cinnamon, powered sugar, chocolate, beans, etc)  When I visited the first time, I had the red beef chile stew early in the day and later returned later that evening with a friend to have the hominy beef stew.  By the time we finished, the place had long closed, and the owners were cool about politely waiting until we finished.

9dC46GYOyRH-h9JdPP_rJA.text: ok..so i had a really good friend who took me here a few times...well not here..actually when it was on Indian School and 7th st. it looks so much more inviting now. i just need to bring myself to want to gorge nom nom nom on some fry bread. it's like a big pile of fried crack. you seriously get hooked on the decadent fried morsals. topped with hot and saveries these are just to kill for. maybe even worth dying for. a sweet one is excelent..nom nom nom. ok i think i need to end this post before i eat my keyboard.

5Ln3f8sTnf8M-BBZdWh6Zw.text: This place was very popular, and there was a line at the door.  The food is very simple cooking, but its door well.  The menu has a lot of variations on he same thing, and items are just different fillings for the fry bread.  You order at the counter and they call you for picking it up.  Dining is simple and spartan.  there is eating area outside too.  Everything our party ordered was good, but I would not give it an off the hook rating.  All in all with the price being cheap, it was a place that I would recommend and visit again.  Excellent for take out due to the limited seating.

hHMNED3iNKT79WoHvCPPYw.text: Tasty food, casual atmosphere.  Add this to your list of favorite local mom and pop ethnic restaurants to take out of town guests, it's one of those unique places that my return visitors tell others about and ask to be taken back to.  If you're lucky you may see former Governor Rose Mofford (beehive hairdo and all) enjoying a frybread in one of the booths.  i'm partial to the frybreads that come with green chili, either on board or on the side.  the powdered sugar and honey one's also very tasty but i usually don't have room for that after a meal...but hey, you could stroll up  7th Ave to checkout some of the cool antique and vintage fashion and art shops in the Melrose neighborhood, then stroll back to FBH for that powdered sugar and honey frybread.  in the past they have sometimes had a live chicken scratch band playing in their parking lot on First Friday night which only adds to the local color.  i need to go by and see if that's still the case -hope so!

UddqAV7VD7OkJUtatlZqYQ.text: You're gonna want to put your eatin' dress on for this place. I have been going to the fry bread house for almost 2 years now and have never had a bad experience. I actually heard about this place from many Phoenicians but wasn't really a fan of fried bread. The food is always phenomenal, the prices are great and you know you're going to leave with a full belly. I went back recently and am not sure if I somehow overlooked it but I noticed that now they have menudo on their menu! Not just served on Saturdays and Sundays like other places. It was excellent! It had a spicy kick to it and was not uber greasy like some places make...actually many places. I find the staff friendly, the environment comfy with all of it's earth tones, and an overall awesome little place to go when you want something hearty. I actually have family that when in town, they come here straight away!

mnGadEvIvOm1hRsDr1sGIQ.text: Have lived in Phoenix Valley four years and waited way too long to visit this place and will not hesitate going back there from Northwest Valley (Surprise). Spouse had taco and I had hominy stew with fry bread and we were delighted and thoroughly satisfied with our meal and service. Nice to have people care about their food and share it with passion to the rest of the world! We will be going back and trying more on the menu! People were so friendly and full of smiles instead of this is just a job face looking at you. The place is clean and has some pretty awesome artwork on the walls. They are now open to 9 pm except on Sunday.  Have not enjoyed a meal so thoroughly since eating at the Cameron Trading Post. The Fry Bread House is definitely a place to visit on a regular basis and if you are a tourist...a must stop!

ovVsz5QnoQXeZ124iS9W7A.text: Gotta love the Fry Bread House! When I grew up we would go to the AZ State Fair just to pick up some Indian fry bread. When I discovered this restaurant I was a happy guy. I often enjoy a fry bread with green chile beef, AND a bowl of red chile stew. I have found that it is good to add on the stew because two fry breads are too much food for me but one fry bread isn't enough. The green chile is spicy but not bad spicy. Slow burn build up spicy with a lot of flavor. The red chile has a terrific earthy slow burn to it as well. The fry bread is Perfect here! If you are from out of town and you want to experience the Southwest, this is one of the places that you should begin your journey!

eu5AzFPhfIzQdOwHg9DQQA.text: Hands down, best fry bread in all of Phoenix. Don't waste your time going anywhere else, I promise you it won't compare to here. I've been eating at this place for the past 13 years(at their different locations) and I swear it's just better every time!

bxYcdxBPuQHPYg_FQPpDYA.text: "I like it so much I'd like to eat here everyday for forever." That was the comment from a four year old when I last ate at the former location of The Fry Bread House. Fortunately, the food remains as good as ever, not harmed at all when the capacity to serve customers expanded.  A great place for visitors to Arizona who want to sample some genuinely regional cuisine, specifically derived from the traditions of the Tohono O'odham. The Native American craft booths are a fun bonus.   Just don't expect much in the way of ambience. You can sense that the building was once a cheap Mexican food cafeteria. Oh well. Just convince yourself it adds to the charm of the establishment.  I must admit that I do miss the sketchy and cramped confines of the old location, but having a little extra room to dine is nice. It must also be great for the Native American craft vendors to have space inside in air conditioning.  The staff has always been friendly to us. I read some reviews on Yelp that complained of inattentive service... Surprising to me. I'm suspicious that some of those negative comments may be the result of cultural miscommunications. We weren't really greeted when we entered on our most recent visit, but the server who brought our food to the table was very engaging and we were warmly sent on our way as we exited. I'd characterize it as a kind of quiet friendliness that you might miss if you aren't accustomed to it.  Save room for dessert!

j8EPbLUsnD4-J7dfJl9jWQ.text: This place is really trying to make a buck off so-so fry bread. I added tomato to my taco and it was a 1.50, that's a lot to me, it's not avocado!
